Class TicTacToe

  • java.lang.Object
    • TicTacToe

  • class TicTacToe
extends java.lang.Object
    TicTacToe - The class performs an ASCII graphic tic-tac-toe game with dynamic gameboard size against an AI player.
    Version:
    2018.1.01
    Author:
    Kalle Lindevall

    • Method Detail

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        Starts the game and keeps it running until a winner is found or the gameboard is full. Later announces the winner.
        Parameters:
        args - the command line arguments

      • NewGame

        public static int NewGame()
        Prints out the rules for the game and then starts the adjustments for the gameboard size, starting by asking an input for the width of the gameboard.
        Returns:
        width for the gameboard

      • BoardHeight

        public static int BoardHeight()
        Asks user input for the height of the gameboard.
        Returns:
        height for the gameboard

      • MarkAmount

        public static int MarkAmount(int gameboardWidth,
                             int gameboardHeight)
        Asks user input for the amount of marks required to win the game.
        Parameters:
        gameboardWidth - value of the width of the gameboard, that is compared to the value of the height
        gameboardHeight - value of the height of the gameboard, that is compared to the value of the width
        Returns:
        the amount of marks required to win the game

      • PrintNewGameboard

        public static void PrintNewGameboard()
        First fills the gameboard with '-' (markEmpty), then prints out the board.

      • PlayGame

        public static void PlayGame()
        Runs the methods for the player turn and the computer turn. Checks for wins after each turn.

      • MovePlayer

        public static void MovePlayer()
        The human player's turn. Asks the input for the coordinates for the player mark 'X'.

      • MoveCPU

        public static void MoveCPU()
        The computer player's turn. Randomizes the values of the coordinates for the computer player mark 'O'.

      • PrintUpdatedGameboard

        public static void PrintUpdatedGameboard(int whichPlayer,
                                         int markRow,
                                         int markCol)
        Prints the gameboard with the human and the computer player's marks updated in it.
        Parameters:
        whichPlayer - used as an identifier to determine which player's mark to put on the board
        markRow - height/row coordinate for the player's mark, used to put the mark in the correct coordinates
        markCol - width/column coordinate for the player's mark, used to put the mark in the correct coordinates

      • CheckWins

        public static char CheckWins()
        Checks if the marks placed by the user/computer form a horizontal, vertical or a diagonal line, containing an equal amount of that player's marks to the user defined amount of marks required to win the game. The loops do this by first going the gameboard through with for-loops and then utilising if-else to check, if the current mark is a mark placed by either of the palyers. If it is, the markCount increases with +1 until an empty mark is checked or the required amount of marks is achieved. markCount is reset when it comes across a '-'.
        Returns:
        either a mark of a player (that also determines the winner), or an empty mark if no winner is found

      • FullBoard

        public static boolean FullBoard()
        Checks if the board is full or not.
        Returns:
        is the gameboard full and no more turns are possible, equaling in a draw.

      • Wait

        public static void Wait(int time)
        A nifty little "extra" method, used to add small delays in the code. The reason for this was already explained in the beginning of the code (line 43), but it's mainly to help with the user experience, by easing the pacing of the output a little bit.
        Parameters:
        time - the amount of milliseconds to wait
